content: The Trump Administration requested $76.2 billion for the Department of Transportation (DOT) for FY2019, proposing significant cuts in funding for various programs. The Department of Transportation (DOT) receives most of its funding from trust funds, with around two-thirds to three-fourths being mandatory budget authority. The Capital Investment Grants program (CIG) is the largest discretionary grant program by the Federal Transit Administration, funding new fixed-guideway transit lines and extensions. It has three components: New Starts grants for projects over $300 million seeking over $100 million in federal funding, Small Starts grants for projects under $300 million seeking less than $100 million in federal funding, and Core Capacity grants for projects increasing existing system capacity by at least 10%. Additionally, there is an Expedited Project Delivery Pilot for projects eligible for any of the three programs seeking no more than a 25% federal share.
